caption.text: Osgood Carleton was one of the major surveyors of eighteenth-century New England. Many surveys of this time focused on boundaries and outlines, but they also provide details about perceived regional geographies.
caption.title: Plan of Boston surveyed by Osgood Carleton, dated 1795.

caption.text: Carleton indicates that many of the significant places in Boston could not be included on this map due to scale.
Carleton identifies one chocolate mill among these places. The location of this mill is difficult to identify.
One possible location is on the Neponset River on the border of Milton and Dorchester.
Mather Withington was another surveyor of eighteenth-century Boston, and this map is from one year earlier than Carleton’s map.
caption.title: Plan of Dorchester made by Mather Withington, dated September, 1794.

caption.text: Withington identifies one chocolate mill in Dorchester. This is the site of Baker Chocolate.
The mill (marked as 11 on this map) was located along the Neponset River, where the flowing water could be used to run the machinery.
But it is likely that the “1 chocolate mill” referenced by Osgood Carleton on the 1795 map was located within the official boundary of Boston. This map from 1797 is also by Carleton.
caption.title: An accurate plan of the town of Boston and its vicinity

caption.text: It is not marked on this map either, but chocolate producer Jonas Welsh owned the building at the corner of Margaret Lane and Sheaf Street from the early 1780s to at least 1798 where he appears on the Clough Atlas (block 300). From this location, we can explore chocolate production in the Early Republic.
